description: From the Ancient Greek τελῐκός (telikós, “final”), from τέλος (télos, “end”).

adjectives.description: telic (comparative more telic, superlative most telic)

entries.meaning: Tending or directed towards a goal or specific end.
examples: They were asked to rate the 36 activities for how purposeful they were. […] Comparing the 10 most telic and the 10 most paratelic we found that the paratelic leisure activities were thought to involve less skill or challenge; they were also judged to satisfy social needs more, and to be more enjoyable.

entries.meaning: (grammar) That expresses an end or purpose.
examples: In this framework, verbs denoting directed change of location, such as Italian andare 'go', instantiate Core Unaccusativity, in that they have a Theme subject and are the most telic, concrete, dynamic.
